Award.AwardTitle: Development of a Micro-baddeleyite (ZrO2) U-series Chronometer for Recent Mafic Lavas
Award.AbstractNarration:
Reconstructing the pre- and post-eruptive chronology of past volcanic eruptions is essential for understanding the patterns of human response to natural disasters, and to devise mitigation strategies for extant volcanic hazards. Despite the maturity of many geochronological techniques applied to date Quaternary volcanic eruptions, considerable uncertainties remain with regard to the timing of magmatic processes culminating in violent eruptions, as well as their environmental impact even for fairly recent events. This research will develop a dating tool for common types of volcanoes characterized by comparatively low silica abundances, which can be difficult to date using existing chronometers. Ultimately, improved age constraints on the eruptive history of such volcanoes will lead to better assessments of their volcanic hazards.

The new chronometer is based on the radioactive decay of uranium intrinsic to the crystal lattice of baddeleyite, a zirconium oxide mineral. Crystal sizes for baddeleyite are typically small, and therefore this research will improve electron-beam techniques for locating micro-baddeleyite crystals in rocks, and develop analytical procedures to analyze baddeleyite via secondary ionization mass spectrometry to detect trace abundances of uranium and its radioactive decay products. Representative volcanoes will be investigated to calibrate the baddeleyite chronometer against other dating techniques. For this, University of California Los Angeles researchers are collaborating with domestic and international volcanologists. Case studies include volcanoes in the Cascades (USA) and the Campanian volcanic province (Italy). These volcanoes represent long-lived volcanic systems with a protracted history of recurrent eruptions over tens to hundred thousands of years. Establishing precise and accurate volcanic chronostratigraphies through baddeleyite uranium disequilibrium dating will ultimately contribute to an improved understanding of magma output rates and eruptive recurrence intervals in a broad range of magmatic environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to understand the style and frequency of past volcanic eruptions provides key information which can guide efforts to monitor volcanoes in order to mitigate societal impacts of future eruptions. Reconstructing the chronology of past volcanic events, however, is often difficult because of the intrinsic limitations of existing radiometric dating tools. Mafic lavas, a dominant component of many stratovolcanoes including those in the Cascades and Alaskan volcanic arc (see image of Mt. Rainier, WA, as an example) are in particular difficult to date by currently available techniques (mainly 14-C and K-Ar dating) because of a “blind spot” for eruption ages between ca. fifty thousand and one million years, where conventional Quaternary geochronometers often fail. The physical reasons for this are (1) the scarcity of organic matter suitable for 14-C dating of lava flows; (2) the limits of 14-C dating (i.e., the essentially quantitative exhaustion of 14-C by radioactive decay after ca. fifty thousand years); and (3) the slow pace at which time-sensitive daughter products accumulate (e.g., 40-Ar through decay of 40-K) which makes these daughter products vulnerable for contamination from sources other than by radioactive decay in the rocks to be dated.

In this project, we have developed and applied a novel tool for dating mafic lavas from Quaternary volcanoes using the mineral baddeleyite, a zirconium oxide which is present in minor quantities in these rocks. In also contains minute but analytically detectable amounts of uranium and thorium. The uranium-thorium (U-Th) decay system has the advantage that (1) isotopic abundances change at a 10,000-times faster rate compared to Ar, (2) these isotopes are highly enriched in baddeleyite so that they overwhelm any external contributions, and (3) the age limit of the U-Th technique (at ca. three hundred thousand years) extends much further than that of 14-C. It was demonstrated through comparison using some well-dated examples of lavas from Campi Flegrei (Italy) that the U-Th analysis of baddeleyite can yield reliable age information for past volcanic eruptions. Detailed investigation of mafic lavas from volcanoes of the Cascades has also documented the presence of baddeleyite in these volcanoes. In the future, this can provide more reliable information on the eruption history of these volcanoes that pose potential volcanic hazards for the western United States and beyond. This project also successfully established collaborations between institutions in the United States and abroad (Istituto Nazionale di Geofisica e Vulcanologia Sezione di Napoli), and provided training of a graduate student in state-of-the-art metrological methodologies and microanalytical instrumentation.
